body: Thank you for the background @guozhangwang. Good to know that it should not longer be an issue.
LGTM. Thank you!
Committed to trunk and 0.9.0 so the corrected docs will ship with 0.9.0.1

@junrao Thank you. Is there plan to use the Apache Security Team or other private channels to report security defects in Kafka? Since 0.9.0.0 has been released, it may be useful to have a security contact for Kafka here - http://www.apache.org/security/projects.html?
Hi @guozhangwang, did you have the chance to take a look at this?
@rajinisivaram : Could you just submit jiras?

Even though LinkedIn doesn't use Solaris anymore, there could be other places use Solaris. Also, not sure if snappy is supported in other platforms like Windows. The intention of using reflection is to make snappy an optional runtime dependency---one only needs to include the snappy jar if snappy compression is still used. This allows people to be able to use Kafka on platforms that can't load the snappy jar. So, it's useful preserve this unless we know loading snappy is not an issue for major operating systems.

@junrao Long term it will be good to have a channel to report security vulnerabilities without impacting secure installations before a fix is available. But for now, we can submit JIRAs and see how it goes.

Thanks for the patch. Looks good overall. Just realized another thing. The propagation of ACLs from AclCommand to the broker is async. So, to avoid transient failures, we will need to call sth like TestUtils.waitAndVerifyAcls() after the acl is set before running the producer and the consumer.

@junrao using `TestUtils.waitAndVerifyAcls()` isn't very realistic because a user won't have access to it. Is there a way for an application to determine whether the ACLs have propagated? If there isn't, then I will use the call you suggest, but I'd rather avoid making such an internal call if possible.
Just in case there isn't a better way, here is the version with the calls to `waitAndVerifyAcls`.
This patch LGTM, merged into both trunk and 0.9.0.

@junrao Snappy supports Linux, Windows, AIX and SunOS. The Snappy jar is included by default (due to the build time dependency), but I think you meant to say that we don't want to trigger the code that extracts the native library files from the jar (which could fail in some platforms) unless the user is actually using Snappy. That's probably the safe thing to do for this patch (although it seems like classloading was happening unnecessarily eagerly if it was causing problems in the `Compressor` code without reflection, I'd actually like to verify that if I actually had some free cycles).

For reference, the Snappy library includes the following native code:

``` text
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Windows/x86_64/snappyjava.dll;osname=win32;processor=x86-64",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Windows/x86_64/snappyjava.dll;osname=win32;processor=x64",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Windows/x86_64/snappyjava.dll;osname=win32;processor=amd64",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Windows/x86/snappyjava.dll;osname=win32;processor=x86",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Mac/x86/libsnappyjava.jnilib;osname=macosx;processor=x86",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Mac/x86_64/libsnappyjava.jnilib;osname=macosx;processor=x86-64",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Linux/x86_64/libsnappyjava.so;osname=linux;processor=x86-64",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Linux/x86_64/libsnappyjava.so;osname=linux;processor=x64",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Linux/x86_64/libsnappyjava.so;osname=linux;processor=amd64",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Linux/x86/libsnappyjava.so;osname=linux;processor=x86",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Linux/aarch64/libsnappyjava.so;osname=linux;processor=aarch64",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Linux/arm/libsnappyjava.so;osname=linux;processor=arm",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Linux/ppc64/libsnappyjava.so;osname=linux;processor=ppc64",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Linux/ppc64le/libsnappyjava.so;osname=linux;processor=ppc64le",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/Linux/s390x/libsnappyjava.so;osname=linux;processor=s390x",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/AIX/ppc/libsnappyjava.a;osname=aix;processor=ppc",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/AIX/ppc64/libsnappyjava.a;osname=aix;processor=ppc64",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/SunOS/x86/libsnappyjava.so;osname=sunos;processor=x86",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/SunOS/x86_64/libsnappyjava.so;osname=sunos;processor=x86-64",
"org/xerial/snappy/native/SunOS/sparc/libsnappyjava.so;osname=sunos;processor=sparc"
```
@guozhangwang : Could you verify that with the patch, we don't need the snappy jar to run Kafka clients and server if snappy is not being used?

If I comment out the `AclCommand` for the cluster ACL, even if I comment out the offset topic creation, I get this error:

```
[2015-11-27 19:20:08,371] ERROR [KafkaApi-0] error when handling request Name:UpdateMetadataRequest;Version:1;Controller:0;ControllerEpoch:1;CorrelationId:0;ClientId:0;AliveBrokers:0 : (EndPoint(localhost,51185,PLAINTEXT),EndPoint(localhost,51186,SSL));PartitionState: (kafka.server.KafkaApis:103)
kafka.common.ClusterAuthorizationException: Request Request(3,127.0.0.1:51186-127.0.0.1:51195,Session(User:O=server,CN=localhost,localhost/127.0.0.1),null,1448652008263,SSL) is not authorized.

```

CC @junrao

Now that I review this, I realize there's some information that I didn't give you (I'm going to blame it on the way our configs are split up right now). The actual tuning we're using is:

```
-Xmx6g -Xms6g -XX:MaxGCPauseMillis=20 -XX:InitiatingHeapOccupancyPercent=35 -XX:G1HeapRegionSize=16M -XX:MetaspaceSize=96m -XX:MinMetaspaceFreeRatio=50 -XX:MaxMetaspaceFreeRatio=80
```

The Metaspace settings replace the PermGen settings that were previously valid (PermGen no longer exists in Java 8). The G1HeapRegionSize setting we found was needed because there were many 3-5 MB allocations (which are considered humongous). This would periodically cause a full GC cycle that could take very long (12-50 seconds), impacting the cluster. This is likely due to our message and batch sizes.
Merged to trunk, but cherry-picking to 0.9.0 failed due to conflicts. cc @benstopford

@rhauch Thanks for sharing your use case, this actually a lot in understanding the motivation. We wanted to be very careful and thoughtful for any new features we added into the framework since we take any of them as big commitment that will carry for a long run. So I want to make sure if the motivation scenarios for any of the new feature requests be common and general enough or if they can be work-around without loosing much programmability.

As for your use case, just want to clarify first that for Kafka Stream's local state, it will use a specific partition of the changelog topic corresponding to its task id that owns the local state, and its log is compaction-enabled by default which will use the message key as the local state's key to obsolete old values. Hence there is no partitioning concerns for its change log. So for your case (a database transaction log stream as source, with multiple services trying to do stateful processing at different levels), one alternative way is to send the source messages with just the partitioning fields as message keys to the corresponding topics for different services, i.e.:

1) send to topic "per-database" with key "<database>" and the row as the value.
2) send to topic "per-collection" with key "<database/collection>" and the row as the value.
3) send to topic "per-group" with key "<database/collection/group>" and the row as the value.

Then for each service's own stateful processors that consume from the above corresponding topic, create their local state with key "<database>/<collection>/<group>/<row>" and row as the whole value, then for each instance of the local state, its changelog will be sending to a single partition with the message key as the state key to garbage collect obsolete data with the same key. The general idea is that we keep using only the fields for partitioning in the normal Kafka topic, and use the combo key for garbage collection of changelog in local states which will not be affecting any partitioning schemes. 

Moving forward we could think about reducing this unnecessary log duplication just for different partitioning schemes by introducing a general hierarchical key-aware partitioner along with the partition assignor so that we will only need to send to a single topic with the key "<database/collection/group>" to O \* P \* Q partitions, while the "per-group" service can create up to O \* P \* Q processors with each getting one partition, and the "per-collection" service can create up to O \* P processors with each get Q partitions that are all from "<database/collection/*>".

Does this make sense? cc @ymatsuda @jkreps

@guozhangwang, I do hope that it is clear that there are valid use cases where Kafka Streams processors do need to explicitly control the partitions to which their messages are sent. And, yes, this is independent of any topics used internally by Kafka Stream state stores, which IMO is very nicely done to ensure proper storage and recovery of the state stores while being almost entirely transparent to any developers creating processors that use state stores.

I tried to keep my description of my use case very simple to avoid small nuances and complexities, but I may have been too abstract to be useful in discussing partitioning alternatives. 

Basically, I have a system that involves multiple _services_, where each service consumes one or more topics, performs some logic that may or may not involve local state stores, and writes output messages to one or more other topics. Let's call these services _A_, _B_, _C_, and _D_ (although I actually have about a dozen of them with well over a dozen different topics), and a typical deployment might have 8 instances of service A, 16 instances of service B, 20 of service C, 5 of service D, etc. Previously I was using Samza, and had a separate job for each kind of service. I did not like Samza's dependency on YARN, and wanted more control over deployment. Kafka Streams seemed ideal, so I created a prototype that uses Kafka Streams, where each kind of service is defined by a simple topology with one or more sources, usually a single processor, and one or more sinks, and I can easily deploy these topologies to as many processes as I'd like.

Although a minority of my services can easily handle _at least once_ delivery, I've gone to great lengths to ensure that the remainder of my services are able to do _exactly once processing_, despite failures that can occur at any time. Most of this was accomplished with very careful design of the state stored locally and the processing logic. As I'm sure you're aware, this logic is more complex when a single processor writes out to more than one topic: any failure of the processor while having written to at least one but not all of the output topics makes it likely that downstream processors (that consume this service's output streams) will see duplicate messages. Since that cannot be prevented entirely, the downstream processors have to be able to detect duplicate messages.

So since writing to multiple output topics greatly complicates a processor's logic for exactly once processing, using multiple topics as a means of controlling partitioning would only exacerbate this complexity, and I would deem it a non-starter for my system.

You also suggest using what I call an "artificial key" that is solely used for implicit partitioning via the global/default partitioner. I've done exactly that in several of my topics, especially in those that contain _events_ rather than _entities_, since they are not candidates for log compaction and thus the key no longer becomes terribly important for consumers.

In cases where the messages do represent _entities_, log compaction is a very important approach to minimize the size of the persisted logs. However, these topics cannot be replaced wholesale by the topics written by the state stores, since they cannot be replayed by downstream consumers. Additionally, the upstream processors shouldn't have to dump all their state to the stream -- that complicates the processor and the whole system, introduces potentially very significant latency, and unnecessarily duplicates persisted data.

I think I've very clearly shown that some Kafka Stream use cases do indeed need to explicitly specify the partitions to which messages are sent, and in these cases how the topics are partitioned becomes an integral part of the system design. I think I've also explained how the global/default partitioner is not very straightforward or efficient for these cases, since any custom global partitioner would have to deal with the specific topics at hand plus delegate to the standard partitioner for all other topics (like those from the stateful stores, offset commits, or any others used by Kafka itself). I hopefully have explained how using "artificial keys" solely for partitioning is great in some situations, but is insufficient in others. Using multiple streams for different partitioning schemes has too much overhead and adds too much complexity to some processors that require exactly once delivery/processing.

All of the issues I've discussed in this PR are easily solved by simply allowing a Kafka Stream topology to explicitly direct messages to specific partitions. So while I completely agree on the importance of keeping the Kafka Streams API as simple and stable as possible, IMO it is a mistake to prevent custom partitioning logic. The proposed PR is a minor change to the public API so that a topology can optionally define a custom partitioner on each sink. It's not mandatory, so all the use cases that don't need to worry about partitioning (other than configuring the number of partitions) don't have to use it. But those use cases that require it have a very simple and straightforward mechanism. 

Hopefully you agree that the Kafka Streams API does need to enable custom partitioning within a topology. Perhaps you don't agree with how this PR does it, in which case we can certainly look at alternative changes. Personally, I think this PR strikes the right balance between minimizing the change to the public API while enabling custom partitioning within the topology itself.
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.9.0.

Thanks for the comments. I have made various improvements based on the suggestions. I came across an issue while making these changes with minikdc. The issue is essentially when we start up, which currently happens in the start method in `kafka.py`. To avoid the issue completely, I used SASL PLAIN because at this point I really just want to test that I'm able to perform a rolling upgrade while enabling ZooKeeper ACLs.

I've been looking at the minikdc issue with @benstopford, and the fix might not be too hard, but in any case let me know if you think that having the minikdc working is a blocker.
